title: What are the three main phases of matter? - Quora

response.answer_text: What are the three “phases” of matter? Three? Those would be: NeutroniumSolidLiquidSuperfluidGasPlasmaFermionic condensateBose-Einstein condensate…hang on just one moment here  So here’s the thing. Traditional teaching holds that there are three phases, solid, liquid, and gas. We even draw phase diagrams showing which of those three you find at different pressures/temperatures. Like this:  But “traditional teaching” also tell us that we have a mere five senses, then declines to mention which of those we use to tell if we’re hot, or hungry, or off-balance. Traditional teaching leaves much to be desired. And those phase diagrams? This is the real one:  Yup… that’s 13 distinct phases of ice alone, all of which are considered a solid. They don’t all float on liquid water either. We’ll also speak of amorphous phases, crystalline phases, semi-crystalline phases, etc. As well as the supercritical fluids and condensates mentioned above, plus the various changes involved as a material cools enough to become superconducting.  TLDR; the very idea of having just three phases is a massive over-simplification. It’s a useful one when educating pre-teens, but it’s a terrible approximation of the real world for any serious scientific or engineering application.
